COMPLIANCE AND ENFORCEMENT MEASURES

Table of Contents

 

 

Do you remember the scenario?

 

 

If PCQ Consulting is prosecuted and found to be guilty, the court may only impose a fine. True or false?

Scenario

 

PCQ Consulting is a large IT consulting business. Its team of consultants travel frequently and share a number of company cars for their visits to clients.

 

After one of its cars breaks down, PCQ is investigated by the Work Health and Safety Regulator.

 

The regulator finds that PCQ has breached its obligations under WHS laws. An investigation reveals that the car was not in roadworthy condition when the accident occurred. Furthermore, the employee had not been appropriately supervised to ensure she only drives cars that are roadworthy.

 

Due to these findings, PCQ entered into an enforceable undertaking to address work practices and organisational safety climate factors that contributed to the occurrence of the accident. To date, PCQ has not addressed these issues.

 

The regulator issues PCQ a notice signalling that it plans to prosecute the organisation for breaching both the enforceable undertaking and its duty of care as a PCBU to its workers.

True, a court can only impose a fine

False

 
 

That is incorrect

 

If a court finds a company guilty of an offence under WHS laws, it may make any of a number of orders, including imposing a fine.

That is correct!

 

If a court finds a company guilty of an offence under WHS laws, it may make any of a number of orders, including imposing a fine.
